Ted Cruz even ripped the legislation as “a Christmas tree” with billions of dollars in extraneous goodies. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR New York and New Jersey Republicans haven’t forgotten the slight. And with Hurricane Harvey wreaking devastation down South — and Congress beginning to contemplate what will likely be a massive aid package — the tough-on-spending Texans could find themselves in an awkward spot. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It's the reason disaster aid has largely been a bipartisan issue in Congress: Every lawmaker's district may, at some point, need federal assistance. And it's also the reason taking a rigid anti-spending stand on disaster relief is a risk: Now that Texas needs help, the lawmakers who once opposed aid to the Northeast are getting nicked by colleagues for hypocrisy. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Many Texas reps and notoriously, @SenTedCruz fought against Sandy aid, so crucial to CT," tweeted Rep. Jim Himes (D-Conn.). "Going with my better angels to fight FOR Texas aid." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The rare public rebuke by two fellow Republicans — and less surprising Democratic criticism — underscores the frustration felt by many lawmakers whose districts were similarly hammered by Sandy. New York and New Jersey ultimately received aid amounting to nearly $60 billion, but not until conservative lawmakers attempted to pay for the package with spending cuts to other domestic programs. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “The United States Senate should not be in the business of exploiting victims of natural disasters to fund pork projects that further expand our debt,” Cruz said at the time. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cruz reiterated his complaint on Monday. The Sandy bill, he said on MSNBC, was "filled w/ unrelated pork." A spokesman for Sen. Jon Cornyn (R-Texas), who also ultimately voted against the final Sandy relief package, emphasized on Twitter that Cornyn was supportive of the measure until "extraneous $ for non-relief items" was added. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It’s unclear whether Cruz will apply the same standards for federal aid this time. On Monday, Cruz said he appreciated assurances from President Donald Trump and Vice President Mike Pence that “full federal assistance” would be ready to help Houston rebuild when the storm fully passes. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR President Donald Trump, too, predicted Monday that there would be "fast" action on a spending bill to send aid to Texas. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It’s unclear how large an aid package will be needed. Rain was still pelting the Houston area late Monday, and the precise extent of the apparently massive damage to the area was uncertain. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But the Trump administration seemed to indicate that more federal aid would be coming. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I think what you’re going to see is that the national government, and we anticipate the Congress, are going to make the resources available to see Texas through the rescue operation, through the recovery,” Vice President Mike Pence said in an interview with Houston’s KTRH. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR House Democratic Leader Nancy Pelosi of California hinted at previous GOP reluctance to authorize disaster aid in a statement issued Monday afternoon. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Republicans must be ready to join Democrats,” she said, “in passing a timely relief bill that makes all necessary resources available through emergency spending.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR There’s no indication yet that congressional leaders are coordinating a relief package.
